history.content:
I don't think anyone else can completely answer this question for you – it really depends on whether you like teaching.  I've personally found it to be both fun and rewarding, but I don't think it's for everyone.

One oft-mentioned "selfish" reason to teach (other than tuition benefits) is that you learn the material better by teaching it.  Although I agree with that assessment, I'd say if that's the only thing motivating you, there are better (i.e. more time-efficient) ways to achieve the goal of deeper understanding.

For completeness, I can list some pros and cons.  (Other TAs, feel free to add to this list.)

Pros:

  1. Teaching is fun
  2. Developing course material, exam questions, etc. is fun
  3. $ (sounds like this isn't relevant to your case though)
  4. Become very familiar with the course material
  5. Sense of responsibility and involvement in the university
  6. Meet and befriend other TAs

Cons:

  1. Time-consuming
  2. Can make you doubt yourself when someone asks a question that you can't answer
  3. A few students try to use office hours as a way to milk TAs for answers to the homework

I'd recommend working as a lab assistant or tutor to get a feel for the job before jumping into a full-on TA position.

children.subject: what are some of the things 20-hour TAs have to do that 8-hour TAs don't? I'd appreciate it if someone could list general responsibilities for each type of TA. I know this will vary greatly for each class, but just want to get an overview (like 20-hour TAs moderate exams while 8-hour TAs don't?).

8-hour TAs might not hold office hours, prepare course content, write / proctor / grade exams, et cetera.

At least in 170, the specific duties of 8/10 hour TAs (i.e. which of the previous that the TA does) are negotiated between them and the professor, and aren't fixed.

You're going to need more than one rec? Also, not all TA jobs are created equal. I can guarantee you that a 20-hour TA for a large class (with a large course staff) like 61A is doing less work than a 20-hour TA for a class where there are only 2 TAs. In other words, for some larger CS classes, the week to week time commitment will be a little more flexible, if you're concerned about that commitment.

There are also 8 hour TA appointments as well.
61A TAs - how time consuming is it for you? Are you able to balance out other things (ex: involvement in extracurriculars/clubs) and get good grades?

history.content:
Is TAing worth the 10-20 hour time if I don't need the monetary benefits?

I'm also doing research, so I'm close with a professor too (not worried about rec letter, etc.)

What are some other reasons that I might be missing out on?
history.subject: TAing worth the time?
